Body: Consonants are distinguished normally by features like place of articulation, manner of articulation, voiced/voiceless, etc. while vowels are usually distingusihed by stuff like tongue's position and roundedness. Why can't a universal methodology be used to classify both of them? Some of them are similar anyway, e.g. /i/ vs /j/
Title: Why are consonants distinguished differently than vowels?

LastEditedUser.AboutMe: I am a researcher at a company that specializes in speech synthesis research. I have a Ph.D. in linguistics from Cornell University, and my areas of specialty are phonology and phonetics. I also have a bachelor's degree in music.
